title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [29 april 1863]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [29 April 1863]
text: wensdayWednesday morningMy dear Walti have just got your letter with the shinplasters didentdidn't you get my letter when mary was here saying i got the other there is no letters miscarries that is directed here i think i have had another attack of the rheumatism but not much in my hands so i can use them but in my neck and shoulders i had not A very good night last night but am better this morning i am in hopes it will wear off without going to mrs pierceys if it dontdon't get better i shall go and take the baths but i think i shall be better of it in a while) are you got well Walt of your cold and deafness) Jeffy had a letter from george mondayMonday he was then in Lexington but was going back to camp the next day they are to winchesterWinchester 16 miles from Lexington he was ordered there to bring the souldierssoldier's money to put in addams s expressAdams Express he came on horseback with 11 thousand dollars all to be sent in packages from 4 to 400 dollar he says he had an wonderful job but it came out right to a cent and the next day he was going back the letter was dated the 22 he likes Kentucky very much is glad he is out of the virginiaVirginia mud he says the roads is like a house floor and good living i see in the mercury last sundaySunday that he was to come with the money but it said to cincennattyCincinnati instead of lexingtonLexington i am glad he is releevedrelieved of the responcibilityresponsibility he sent home 300 and 50 dollars i got it yesterday and am going to the bank to day but i cantcan't put but 200 and 50 in i will tell you Walt all about it before i got it Mat and Jeff began to hint about their having it i would not mind lending Jeff but it seems as if martha had no thought whatever Jeff is very much in debt and no steady work he has had 50 dollars of georges money and it will go in short order for things they could be just as well ofoff without i told mat the other day she knowed what expenceexpense it would be when she was sick and i would not get noremore than i needed but its no use the other 50 i had to pay my grocery bill which has been ever since before you went away i believe it was not 30 dollars i did not want to lend them but 25 dollars i said i had my grocery to pay and i wanted to have some to send for han but i could doodo no different without giving offence George wants me to try to get a litlelittle place in the country somewhere i would like to have put 300 in the bank but so it is we live very saving indeed but things is very high i have got 2 10 dollar bills left if i send for hanna i shall need them mary says she will go what doodo you think of it i dont know how it would doodo write to me Walter what do you think) dontdon't write Walt any thing what i have said about the money i have not seen Andrew in some days but i think he is on the gain a little) Jim comes round to see me quite often comes after cake his father says Mr Howel was here the same morning he returndreturned poor man he said you was very kind to him indeed good bie my dear walt Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [29 April 1863]
